slide.text: ##Why do we get a positive number when we multiply two negative numbers? When we multiply or divide two negative numbers, the result is a positive number. This might seem strange at first, but it's important to remember that a negative sign in math is really just an instruction to change the direction of a number on a number line. So when we multiply or divide two negative numbers, we're reversing the direction twice, which brings us back to a positive number. For example, we would show $3 \times 4$ as $3$ jumps, each $4$ units long and to the *right*, because $4$ is positive. We would start at $0$, then reach $4$, $8$, and $12$. So $3\times 4=12$. For example, we would show $3 \times -4$ as $3$ jumps, each $4$ units long and to the *left*, because $-4$ is negative. We would start at $0$, then reach $-4$, $-8$, and $-12$. So $3\times -4=-12$. When we multiply by a negative number, we go in the opposite direction than we normally would. So, we would show $-3 \times -4$ as $3$ backwards jumps, each $4$ units long. A regular jump of $-4$ would go to the left, so a backward jump goes to the *right*. We would start at $0$, then reach $4$, $8$, and $12$. So $-3\times -4=12$. Try it yourself with our [Multiplying negative numbers exercise](/e/multiplying_and_dividing_negative_numbers). ## What's the deal with negative signs in fractions? The same rules apply to fractions as they do to whole numbers. A negative sign before a fraction means the whole fraction is opposite of the value without the negative sign. But we can also have a negative sign in the numerator (top of the fraction) or denominator (bottom of the fraction). So is the fraction negative or positive when there is more than one negative sign? Each negative sign before the fraction or in the numerator is the same as multiplying the fraction by $-1$. For example, if we have the fraction $-\dfrac{-3}{8}$, that is the same as $\dfrac{3}{8}$ multiplied by $-1$ twice. $\begin{align} -\dfrac{-3}{8} &=\dfrac{3}{8} \cdot -1\cdot -1 \\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{8} \cdot 1\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{8} \end{align}$ If the negative sign is in the denominator, that is the same as dividing the fraction by $-1$. For example, if we have the fraction $\dfrac{9}{-7}$, that is the same as $\dfrac{9}{7}$ divided by $-1$. $\begin{align} \dfrac{9}{-7} &= \dfrac{9}{7} \div -1\\\\ &= -\dfrac{9}{7} \end{align}$ Try it yourself with our [Negative signs in fractions exercise](/e/negative-signs-in-numerators-and-denominators). ## Are there any special rules for order of operations with negative numbers? There are not any special rules, but we do need to know where a couple more operations fit. The negative sign is the same as multiplying the term by $-1$, so it happens in the same stage as multiplication and division. For example, in the expression $-3^2$, we apply the exponent first, then the negative sign. $\begin{align} -3^2&=-1\cdot 3 \cdot 3\\\\ ^=-9 \end{align}$ However, in the expression $(-3)^2$, the negative sign is inside the parentheses. So we apply the negative sign first, then the exponent. $\begin{align} (-3)^2&=-3 \cdot -3\\\\ &=9 \end{align}$ We've also learned about absolute value. So first of all, the absolute value symbols are a grouping symbol. We perform the operations inside the absolute value symbol during the same stage as we evaluate work inside of parentheses. Then, we actually apply the absolute value during the same stage as we apply exponents and roots. That is because $|x|=\sqrt{x^2}$. Let's try it all together. What is the value of $3-7\cdot |5-8|-4^3$? $\begin{align} 3-7\cdot |5-8|-4^3 &= 3-7\cdot |-3|+4 &\text{Grouping symbols}\\\\ &=3-7\cdot 3 -64 &\text{Exponents and absolute value}\\\\ &=3-21-64&\text{Multiplication}\\\\ &=-82&\text{Addition and subtraction} \end{align}$ Try it yourself with our [Order of operations with negative numbers exercise](/e/order_of_operations).

##Summary Expression | Quotient | Example - | - | - positive $\div$ positive | positive | $6\div 2=3$ negative $\div$ negative | positive | $-6\div (-2)=3$ negative $\div$ positive | negative | $-6\div 2=-3$ positive $\div$ negative | negative | $6\div (-2)=-3$ *Want to learn more about dividing negative numbers? Check out [this video](/v/dividing-positive-and-negative-numbers).* ##Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to try some more dividing negative numbers problems? Check out [this exercise](/e/dividing-negative-numbers).*

## Summary Expression | Product | Example - | - | - positive $\times$ positive | positive | $2\times3=6$ negative $\times$ negative | positive | $-2\times(-3)=6$ negative $\times$ positive | negative | $-2\times 3=-6$ positive $\times$ negative | negative | $2\times(-3)=-6$ *Want to learn more about multiplying negative numbers? Check out [this video](/v/multiplying-positive-and-negative-numbers).* *Want to know why multiplying two negative numbers equals a positive number? Check out [this video](/v/why-a-negative-times-a-negative-makes-intuitive-sense).* ##Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to try some more multiplying negative numbers problems? Check out [this exercise](/e/multiplying_and_dividing_negative_numbers).*

slide.text: The order of operations are one set of agreements for how to evaluate expressions. They make sure everyone gets to the same value. **$\purpleE{\text{G}}$rouping:** We evaluate what's inside grouping symbols first, before anything else. For example, $2\times \purpleE{(3+1)}=2\times4=8$. Two common types of grouping symbols are parentheses and the fraction bar. [[☃ explanation 1]] **$\blueE{\text{E}}$xponents:** We evaluate exponents before multiplying, dividing, adding, or subtracting. For example, $2\times\blueE{3^2} = 2\times9=18$. [[☃ explanation 2]] **$\maroonE{\text{M}}$ultiplication and $\maroonE{\text{D}}$ivision:** We multiply and divide before we add or subtract. For example, $1+\maroonE{4\div 2}=1+2 = 3$. **$\goldE{\text{A}}$ddition and $\goldE{\text{S}}$ubtraction:** Lastly, we add and subtract. Many people memorize the order of operations as $\purpleD{\text{G}}\blueE{\text{E}}(\maroonE{\text{MD}})(\goldE{\text{AS}})$ (pronounced as it's spelled), where the "G" is for grouping, the "E" is for exponents, and so on. Important note: When we have more than one of the same type of operation, we work from left to right. This can matter when subtraction or division are on the left side of your expression, like $4-2+3$ or $4\div2*3$ (see example 3 below to understand why this matters). ##Example 1 **Evaluate $6 \times 4 + 2 \times 3$.** There are no parentheses or exponents, so we jump straight to multiplication and division. $\phantom{=}6 \times 4 + 2 \times 3$ | ${}$ - | - $=\maroonE{6 \times 4} + 2 \times 3$| Multiply $\maroonE6$ and $\maroonE{4}$. $=24 + \maroonE{2 \times 3}$| Multiply $\maroonE2$ and $\maroonE{3}$. $=\goldE{24 + {6}}$| Add $\goldE{24}$ and $\goldE{6}$. $=30$ | ... and we're done! Notice: We took care of all multiplication before doing the addition. If we had done $24+2$ before multiplying $2\times 3$, we would have gotten the wrong answer. ##Example 2 **Evaluate $6^2-2(5+1+3)$.** $\phantom{=}6^2-2(5+1+3)$ | ${}$ - | - $={6}^ 2- 2(\purpleE{5+1+3})$ | Add $\purpleE{5+1+3}$ inside the parentheses first. $=\blueE{6}^\blueE 2- 2({9})$| Find $\blueE{6^2}$, which is $6\cdot 6 = 36$. $={36}-\maroonE{2({9})}$| Multiply $\maroonE2$ and $\maroonE{9}$. $=\goldE{{36}-{18}}$ | Subtract $18$ from ${36}$. $=18$ | ... and we're done! ##Example 3 **Evaluate $7-2+3$.** One correct way to do this is to work from left to right. Correct | Incorrect -|- $\begin{align}&7-2+3\\\\=&5+3\\\\=&8\end{align}$ | $\begin{align}&7-2+3\\\\=&7-5\\\\=&2\end{align}$ Remember: Even though "A" comes before "S" in GE(MD)(AS), that doesn't mean we need to add before we subtract. Addition and subtraction are at the same "level" in the order of operations. The same is true of multiplication and division. *Want to learn more about order of operations? Check out [this video](/v/introduction-to-order-of-operations).* ##Practice [[☃ graded-group-set 1]] *Want to practice more problems like these? Check out [this introductory exercise](/e/order_of_operations_2) and these more challenging exercises: [exercise one](/e/evaluating-numerical-expressions-with-exponents) and [exercise two](/e/order_of_operations).*
